raw_text:
US woman sues over cartridges
 
 A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), saying its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date.
 
 The unnamed woman from Georgia says that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer that it needs re-filling even when it does not. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's biggest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change.
 
 But the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty. "The smart chip is dually engineered to prematurely register ink depletion and to render a cartridge unusable through the use of a built-in expiration date that is not revealed to the consumer," the suit said. The lawsuit is asking for restitution, damages and other compensation. The cost of printer cartridges has been a contentious issue in Europe for the last 18 months. The price of inkjet printers has come down to as little as £34 but it could cost up to £1,700 in running costs over an 18-month period due to cartridge, a study by Computeractive Magazine revealed last year. The inkjet printer market has been the subject of an investigation by the UK's Office of Fair Trading (OFT), which concluded in a 2002 report that retailers and manufacturers needed to make pricing more transparent for consumers.
llama3.2:1b: A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP) over its printer cartridges, claiming they are secretly programmed to expire on certain dates despite not being low on ink.
The lawsuit seeks restitution and damages from individuals who purchased HP inkjet printers since 2001.

The lawsuit seeks compensation for anyone who purchased an HP printer since 2001.

The lawsuit seeks representation for all US buyers of HP inkjet printers since 2001 and seeks restitution, damages, and other compensation.
Cartridge costs have been a significant concern in Europe for the past year.

qwen2.5:3b: A US woman sues Hewlett Packard (HP) over its inkjet printer cartridges, claiming they are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date, despite being full of ink.
The unnamed Georgia resident alleges chips inside the cartridges prematurely register depletion and render them unusable through a hidden expiration date.
The lawsuit seeks restitution, damages, and compensation for US consumers who purchased HP inkjets since February 2001.
The cost of printer cartridges has been controversial in Europe; UK's OFT investigated pricing transparency issues in the market.
opencoder:1.5b: A US woman suing over cartridges is engaging in a lawsuit accusing HP of exposing a chip inside its ink cartridges, suggesting the printer re-fill cartridge contents even when no ink remains.
The suit seeks compensation from any person who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001, demanding refutation by HP.
It also calls on the market to adjust its pricing strategy as it relates to cost of ink cartridges, which has seen a decrease in Europe's last 18 months.
smollm:1.7b: The US woman sues over HP ink cartridges because they allegedly have a chip inside them that tells the printer when it needs re-filling, even if the printer is not empty.
The chip also shuts down the cartridge at a predetermined date regardless of whether it is empty.
This is a violation of consumer rights and the company's duty to ensure that consumers are not misled about the quality or functionality of their products.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The US woman is suing HP because their printer ink cartridges were secretly programmed to expire on a fixed date even when they weren't empty.
The chip inside each cartridge allows printers to refill ink only when it's "low," which could lead to unusable cartridges.
HP declined to comment on the lawsuit, highlighting the ongoing issue in Europe about printer ink costs and the need for transparency from retailers and manufacturers.
tinyllama:1.1b: A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard over its secretly programmed printer cartridges, claiming they expire on an unannounced date.
The legal action seeks the reimbursement of all cartridges purchased by HP customers since February 2001 and damages for alleged "malfunction" and "uninformed redeplacement".
The lawsuit claims that the printers' chips also shut down ink deposits on a predetermined date, regardless of whether they are empty.
The suit's plaintiff is an unnamed woman from Georgia, claiming that HP's printer cartridges "secretly programme" themselves to expire on an unannounced date, even if their inks are still full.
tinydolphin:1.1b: A US woman claims Hewlett-Packard's inkjet printers contain hidden programmed cartridges that expire on a fixed date, resulting in a premature depletion of the ink.
The suit seeks to represent anyone in the US who purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001.
The lawsuit also claims that the chips within the cartridges are set to register when they run low, regardless of whether they're completely depleted.
However, the lawsuit suggests that a built-in expiration date is used by HP as an incentive to keep users up to date about their ink supplies.

The lawsuit seeks compensation for anyone who has bought an HP inkjet printer since 2001.
The smart chips inside the cartridges also shut down at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are full.
HP declined to comment, and the issue of high printer cartridge costs has been a contentious topic in Europe.

The lawsuit seeks compensation, damages, and other benefits.
This issue has been debated in Europe for 18 months, with printer cartridges costing up to £1700 in running costs over an 18-month period due to cartridge prices.
The UK's Office of Fair Trading (OFT) investigated the market, concluding that retailers and manufacturers need to make pricing more transparent for consumers.

However, the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date.

The cost of printer cartridges has been a contentious issue in Europe for 18 months, with studies showing inkjet printers can cost up to £1,700 in running costs over an 18-month period due to cartridge expenses.
stablelm2:1.6b: A US woman is suing HP, claiming their printer ink cartridges are programmed to expire on specific dates, even when they're not low on ink.
The suit seeks compensation for anyone who purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2016.
HP's chip technology senses ink depletion and advises users to change the cartridge, but it also shuts down the cartridge at a predetermined date.
The woman's lawsuit claims that this dual-engineering purposefully renders cartridges unusable.
She is asking for restitution, damages, and other compensation.
This issue has been debated in Europe with the price of inkjet printers decreasing up to £1 per cartridge, while cartridge replacement costs could rise up to £1,000 per month.
granite3.1-dense:2b: A Georgia woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP) over allegedly manipulated ink cartridges, claiming they contain chips that prematurely trigger an "expiration" date, even when the cartridges still have ink.

The lawsuit, which seeks restitution and damages for US consumers who bought HP inkjet printers since February 2001, alleges these smart chips also mislead users into believing their cartridges are empty.
This case echoes consumer concerns in Europe regarding the high cost of inkjet printer running expenses, which can reach up to £1,700 over 18 months.
The UK's Office of Fair Trading (OFT) previously found that pricing for these products needed greater transparency due to exorbitant costs.
HP's response to this lawsuit remains undisclosed.

The suit argues that the chip prematurely registers ink depletion and enforces an undisclosed expiration date.
It seeks restitution, damages, and other compensation.
The high cost of printer cartridges has been a contentious issue, with a UK study revealing significant running costs.
The UK's Office of Fair Trading previously investigated the inkjet printer market, calling for more transparent pricing.
